He also proved by experiment, that the rays of light in passing 
very near solid bodies are separated into coloured fringes, which 
with a high degree of probability he attributed to their different 
degrees of flexibility. *
With these principles & facts present to his view, it appears 
somewhat strange that Newton should have gone so far out 
of his way for the cause of coloured rings, as to attribute them 
to a plate of Air, & suppositious fits of easy reflection & 
 refraction of the rays of light, when a cause more obvious & 
more simple was at hand; namely, <u>the interference of 
the reflecting & refracting strata of the contiguous surfaces 
of transparent bodies<\u>. It must not be overlooked however, 
that Newton was destitute of all the advantages of later 
discoveries; that had he pursued his experiments (which were 
confessedly left in an unfinished state) as far as he intended, 
he no doubt would have been the first to have discovered and 
acknowledged the weakness of his own Hypothesis. 
This new Theory may be illustrated by referring to figure 
18 & 19. let AB in fig 18, be a piece of plate glass, & CD a lens 
laid theron, the point of contact being at E. let the dotted 
borders represent the external refracting strata, supposed to 
extend to an extreamly small indefinite  distance from each 
surface; the dotted circles will represent Newtonian Rings, 
whose boundaries will be at F & G where the strata cease 
to interfere. 
Let A.B. in fig. 19 represent the section of part of a 
magnified soap bubble, or thin glass globe; let the dotted 
borders represent the refracting strata of the internal sur-
faces of the plate of water, or of Glass; the boundaries of 
colours be at C, & E, where the strata cease to interfere, 
& beyond which the plate is too thick to produce colour. 
the point D will be the thinnest part of the bubble where the
